awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Building with Carbon: Improving Construction Materials with Nanocarbon Additives from Natural Gas
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is the improvements to the strength, durability, and longevity of concrete infrastructure and construction materials with novel graphene-rich carbon nanomaterial additives. Advancement of this technology area (advanced materials/nanomaterials for infrastructure applications) will directly reduce the costs of construction and maintenance ($165B/year in public spending) while supporting the nation's core economic activities ($14T/year in transported goods). The enhanced strength and longevity of nanocarbon coatings and concrete composites will reduce the amount of raw material required to meet specifications resulting in a net reduction of greenhouse gas emissions (concrete production is responsible for 7% of global GHG emissions). The innovation will enhance scientific understanding of the effect of graphene-rich additives on the permeability and strength of concrete and coating composites using both advanced analytical techniques (x-ray tomography) and industry standard procedures (ASTM testing). It will also enhance understanding of the processing required (e.g. functionalization and dispersion) to integrate graphene-rich additives into polyurethane materials and concrete. Additionally, the project will help refine the plasma-based process conditions to produce carbon materials optimized for these applications.

This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project will demonstrate enhancement of mechanical properties and impermeability of construction materials' concrete and concrete coatings using graphene-rich nanocarbon additives derived from microwave plasma conversion of natural gas. The permeability of concrete is its primary pitfall and is responsible for the two most common causes of failure: carbonation and chloride contamination. Sealants can extend concrete's lifespan but are expensive to apply and often deteriorate rapidly due to environmental effects (UV, chemicals, mechanical abrasion). Graphene additives can enhance the barrier properties and mechanical strength of concrete and sealants, but are currently too costly for construction and infrastructure applications. The objective of this project is to enhance the barrier and mechanical properties of concrete and sealants using a novel graphene-based carbon nanomaterial produced using a cost-effective, scalable, plasma-based process. Carbon nanomaterials will be produced at varied process conditions and, following post-treatment and functionalization, will be incorporated into polyurethane formulations and concrete mixtures. Water and chloride penetration into composites will be examined using advanced x-ray tomographic 3D imaging. Composites will undergo further testing in accordance with AASHTO/ASTM-standards. The anticipated results will establish the technical benefits of using graphene-based nanocarbon additives in concrete and sealants.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Through the work completed in this Phase I project, H Quest developed and demonstrated a simple, scalable, low-cost process for manufacturing a novel concrete-admixture that renders significant improvements to the strength, durability and conductivity characteristics of concrete and cement. Based on the unique graphene-enriched nanocarbon materials co-produced with zero-CO2 hydrogen via microwave plasma pyrolysis, manufacturing of this product can enable improvements in the longevity and reliability of public infrastructure, reducing the financial and environmental costs of maintenance and new construction.

Empirical studies completed during the project relied on H Quest's microwave plasma prototype system to produce the graphene-rich carbon materials. A facile functionalization technique developed during the course of the work enabled dispersion of these carbons into aqueous media, and subsequent incorporation into concrete mixtures. Their value as a potential admixture in cement were established through material characterization and fundamental property analysis at partnering academic institutions, and further confirmed through AASHTO/ASTM-standard testing at third-party laboratories. 

The sheer volume and the impact of the concrete industry presents an immense opportunity for reducing its environmental footprint: 8% of global CO2 emissions. Degradation of reinforced concrete is the primary driver of concrete consumption for the needs of the nation's transportation infrastructure. H Quest's carbon admixture can significantly improve the strength and durability of cement, enabling direct and indirect reductions in its use and in associated GHG emissions. emissions. The development and eventual commercial adoption of H Quest's product enabled by this project will have a broad positive societal impact: it will boost the longevity of domestic infrastructure, enhance public safety, improve the life cycle sustainability profile of concrete, save taxpayer dollars, and spur additional research into advanced carbon products. Additionally, the additive's conductivity may enable new applications such as heated concrete and infrastructure integrity sensors. Overall, this effort supports America's economic competitiveness through more efficient and effective spending on domestic infrastructure, as well as positive effects for the general public, including improved air quality due to reduced emissions and safer infrastructure. 

Beyond its applications in the concrete industry, H Quest's electrically-driven pyrolysis of natural gas is an inherently zero CO2 process, lending itself to the use of low-cost intermittent renewable energy. By liberating hydrogen with a 75% lower energy requirement than electrolysis, it sequesters elemental carbon directly within a valuable co-product. Development and deployment of these plasma pyrolysis processes can support sustainability improvements of multiple hard-to-decarbonize sectors.


Last Modified: 12/08/2021
Modified by: George Skoptsov
